titlestmt.titleproper: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare Interests - Youth, Series R
A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare Interests - Youth, Series R FA327

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-03-01 00:40:52 -0500.

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare Interests - Youth, Series R

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains 47 boxes of documents covering the years 1897 to 1961. This is a companion series to the Welfare General material and reflects the interest of the Rockefeller family, in particular John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and John D. Rockefeller 3rd, with issues and organizations specifically focused on American youth. The involvement of Mr. Rockefeller Jr. with the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) and Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) dominates this series, accounting for 27 of the 47 boxes. The substantial material on these two organizations reflects both Mr. Rockefeller's strong Christian background and his choice of these agencies as the philanthropic vehicle for a variety of activities--missionary outreach, settlement work, sex education lectures, urban recreation, and the Training Camp activities during the World War I. However, most of the material in this series describes the support given to local Ys in the United States and abroad. The strong interest of Laurance S. Rockefeller and Mary French Rockefeller in the work of the YMCA and YWCA also is evident from these documents.

The next largest block of material, seven boxes in all, concerns John D. Rockefeller 3rd's work with American Youth Hostels. This organization sponsored youth tours in the United States and Europe combined with inexpensive accommodations. Mr. Rockefeller served as president of the organization for a number of years during the late 1940s and early 1950s. These files contain much information on the administrative, financial, and programmatic aspects of the operation.

The remainder of the material in the Welfare Youth Series is distributed across a variety of organizations in the child welfare and youth fields. There are sections on office involvement with the Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Big Brothers, Children's Village, and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. The interest of other family members, particularly from the fourth generation, is also included.

did.unittitle: Young Women's Christian Association - National Board - Centennial Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presentation of appraisal and plans to raise over $5,000,000 between 1950-1955. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1950 contribution to liberalize Pension Fund, $250,000; Mary French Rockefeller acted as General Chairman of Young Women's Christian Association Centennial. 1952 John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gift for endowment of Board, $258,000; 1952 plans for Centennial Observance and Development program. Rockefeller Brothers Fund plans for giving; appeals to Foundations. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. joins sponsoring citizens committee for Centennial Celebration. Mary French Rockefeller's appearance on television show to aid campaign. Gifts by Laurance S. Rockefeller, Mary French Rockefeller, Nelson Rockefeller, Abby Rockefeller Mauz, Winthrop Rockefeller; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. $500,000 gift, 1955. Success of campaign; plans for use of money. Correspondents include Mrs. A. F. Anderson, Margaret E. Burton, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur Jones, Dana S. Creel, Mary French Rockefeller, Nelson A. Rockefeller.
